title: Which is correct, grammatically, 'you are the best thing that (has) ever happened to me' or ' you are the best thing that (have) ever happened to me'? - Quora

response.answer_text: The more I thought about these sentences, the more I understood the reasons they are confusing from a foreign student’s perspective; so I will try to explain what the best option is, and why, using the barest of grammatical terms, which sometimes can be off-putting. The correct choice is “You are the best thing that ever (HAS) happened to me.” Here’s why: First our sentence has 2 parts, called clauses, the first: “You …are the best thing”, (the word ”that”) introduces the second, which is : “has ever happened to me. “ If you were to re-word the sentence, what would you get? “The best thing that ever has happened to me, is you.”This shows that YOU is not REALLY the subject of the sentence, rather “THE BEST THING” as a CONCEPT or IDEA of “someTHING”, is the subject; and since a “thing” is inanimate, therefore 3rd person singular: i.e. I have, you have, he, she , it HAS. Confused? The added problem in all of this is the pronoun “You” requiring a bit of English Language History. From Old to Middle to Early Modern English there were 3 singular pronouns: I, Thou, He/She/It, and 3 for the plural: We/You/They. Soon YOU meaning singular AND plural became more common, and by the mid 1800’s people weren’t using THOU at all in common speech (except for some religious sects even today.) What is one supposed to use, and what verb form ? The matter was settled by using the 2nd person plural YOU, along with its plural verb form, to cover BOTH singular and plural. How do you tell the difference? By context. Two final points: 1. it is perfectly acceptable in the original sentence to say: “You are the best thing that ever…. happened to me,” eliminating “has”: In that case you are simply changing the past tenses, from compound to simple past. And 2. You will also hear “You are the best thing that has ever happened to me,” with “ever” in between “has” and “happened” in the compound past. I myself likely would say something similar, and I have heard it in colloquial speech as well. (To me, it places the stress on “ever”, whereas placing it before “has” sounds somewhat stilted.) Nonetheless it is frowned upon by some purists., who prefer “You are the best thing that ever has happened to me.” I make no judgment here. I hope this helps.

The main clause is “You are the best thing.” The subject is “you,” the verb is “are” and “the best thing” is a predicate complement, specifically a predicate nominative. Then there is a subordinate clause modifying “best thing.” Its subject is the relative pronoun “that,” which stands for “best thing,” and therefore it’s singular. Therefore you want a singular verb form, “has” if you’re using the present perfect tense. If the main clause had been something like “Those are the best things,” then the relative pronoun “that” would stand for “best things” and would be plural, and the verb would have to be the plural form “have.” The point is that “you” is not the subject of the verb in the subordinate clause. It’s the subject of the verb in the main clause, and the verb is “are” which is the appropriate form for “you.” The subordinate clause has its own subject and its own verb. In other words, the sentence isn’t saying “you … have happened to me”; it’s saying “… the best thing … has happened to me.” Native speakers of English don’t consciously analyze sentences that way. We have learned how the language works and we do the right thing without thinking about it. Which is correct, grammatically, "you are the best thing that (has) ever happened to me" or " you are the best thing that (have) ever happened to me"?
